Award.AwardTitle: CS 10K: Computer Science: Creating A Village for Educators (CS:CAVE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of California San Diego (UCSD) proposes a project "Computer Science: Creating A Village for Educators (CS: CaVE)" to design, support, and test the efficacy and sustainability of a district-based model for scaling and providing sustained support for teacher professional development to teach the new Advanced Placement (AP) Computer Science Principles (CSP) course. CSP focuses on computer science principles, providing students with a foundational understanding of the underlying logic, grammar, thinking and communication skills, and problem-solving approaches of computational thinking. Courses and curricula meeting the AP CSP learning objectives have been piloted at a number of sites but a major obstacle persists: the lack of professional secondary school educators capable of teaching CSP effectively. Using proven curriculum and pedagogy developed through a UCSD CS Principles pilot project, CS: CaVE aims to provide a model for building, growing and sustaining a regional community of high school CS Principles teachers. It creates "villages" for educators, with district- and peer-based supports for introduction of new curricular and pedagogical content. This district-based "village" model prepares CS Principles Master Teachers within each district and develops effective, sustainable supports for new CS Principles teachers.

Systemic educational change requires district-level support to be launched, incrementally scaled, and sustained. For schools and teachers, districts translate curricular change in the context of policy and administrative requirements at the local and state level. The district-based "village" model being tested and evaluated in this project develops district master teachers as well as local and distributed, in-person and virtual peer support designed to persist after external funding ends. If successful, the project will introduce and scale a new AP CS Principles course through three major secondary school districts within San Diego County. Equally important, it will create a university-connected, district-based training structure for keeping the course (and related computing courses) current as new technologies and global challenges place increasing demands on the workforce skills and knowledge needed by high school graduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer Science: Creating a Village for Educators (CS-CaVE) shows a track record of success in CS implementation. UC San Diego resaerchers from CREATE, the San Diego Supercomputer Center, and Education Studies worked closely with three districts San Diego Unified (2nd largest in California), Sweetwater Union HIgh School District (largest secondary only district in California) and Vista Unified School District (approximately 22,000 students) to build communities of computer science (CS) teachers within and across the three districts. Importantly, the work of CS-CaVE and its district, school, and teacher partners was about uncovering the challenges and often hidden barriers to CS implementation and course creation within districts. And, perhaps even more importantly, the work of the project was also to work alongside districts and schools to overcome these challenges through shifts of resources, approaches, policies and infrastructure, including personnel and funding. Focus of the project was primarily, but not exclusively, on Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles (AP CSP).

Intellectual Merit – In CS-CaVE, an NSF CS10K project (Yonezawa, PI, originally co-PI; Simon, co-PI; Sweet, evaluator) we purposely engaged district leadership as a critical layer of CS educator development efforts. CS-CaVE's work with three San Diego County districts and their teachers to spread CS training and courses deep into schools, aimed at long-term systemic change by tapping the knowledge of the larger educational ecosystem that includes policy, teacher credentialing, graduation requirements, and funding. CS-CaVE has revealed how districts can tackle AP CSP implementation differently to produce long-term investment in CS for example how they focus on development of CS in Career College and Technical Education (CCTE) and CS in content areas such as mathematics. By examining the three districts’ implementations of AP CSP, the research sheds light on how districts can build and communities, including higher education institutions, can help sustain regional AP CSP courses/pathways. 

Broader Impact – CS-CaVE has resulted in dozens of high school teachers trained and actively teaching 190 CSP (mostly AP CSP) classes across the three districts 2014/15-2018/19. This has resulted in approximately 5,700 high school students taking Computer Science Principles or AP Computer Science Principles, annually, and over the (3 years initial and subsequent no-cost extension years) grant period has resulted in over 20,000 students taking these courses in the SD Region. In addition, CS-CaVE has resulted in the fostering and creation of several district and county level investments in computer science teacher development. Most notably, all of the partner districts have created funded "computer science teachers on special assignment roles" housed within their CCTE or general curriculum and instruction offices. They have also created County Office CS regional coordinators. Simultaneously, UC San Diego CREATE has become the regional home of additional computer science national grants, the regional partner of Code.org, and the home of the San Diego Computer Science Teachers Association (SD-CSTA). Together these entities continue to serve the computer science teachers in the region and target services and teacher development in low-income, underrepresented student communities. 

In addition, the CS-CaVE project has focused on sustaining teacher development long-term in ways that meet both new Computer Science California State Standards and teacher credentialing requirements. More specifically, CS-CaVE also supported the cultivation of a new online series of coursework developed by co-PI Simon that will allow for far more California teachers to qualify for a CS supplemental credential across the state over the next decade. This supplemental credential, which is required in California for non-math and non-information technology/business credential teachers to teach secondary CS, will be essential to continuing to ensure that all schools have access to qualified  CS teachers for their student bodies. CS-CaVE's contribution was in part to identify early these types of teacher community development "moves" as needs of the districts and schools. This occured in part through the robust partnership and research of CS-CaVE UC San Diego team members (CREATE, San Diego Supercomputer Center, and Education Studies) with their highly committed district and school partners. 

 

Publications – Yonezawa, S., Renner, N., Sweet, M., Simon, B. & Baxter, D. (2015).
